private_information: I can only pick up and place blocks whose labels are vowels (A, E, I).
I can only manipulate blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I can move only one block at a time, and I can place a block either on the table or on top of another block.
vowel_agent.goal: Contribute to rearranging the blocks from the initial configuration to the specified global target stack by executing legal moves on vowel-labelled top blocks.

private_information: I can only pick up and place blocks whose labels are consonants (all letters except A, E, I, O, U).
I can only manipulate blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I can move only one block at a time, and I can place a block either on the table or on top of another block.
consonant_agent.goal: Contribute to rearranging the blocks from the initial configuration to the specified global target stack by executing legal moves on consonant-labelled top blocks.

private_information: I coordinate the two agents and must integrate their local models and constraints into a single global planning model.
The final PDDL must be compatible with the FastDownwards planner.
orchestrator.goal: Produce a unified PDDL domain and problem that achieves the global goal using actions of both agents kept distinct and compatible with the FastDownwards solver.

public_information: This is a block manipulation domain on a single table.
There are 14 uniquely labeled blocks: L, M, F, C, G, A, H, J, B, D, E, N, I, K.
Initial stacks are given as bottom-to-top arrays: [L, E, I, K], [M, F, H, J, N], [C], [G, A, B, D].
Agents can only interact with blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
Agents can only move one block at a time.
A block can be placed either on the table or on top of another block.
One agent is restricted to vowel-labelled blocks (A, E, I) and the other to consonant-labelled blocks (all other labels).
The global goal is a single tall stack with bottom-to-top order N, M, L, K, J, I, H, G, F, E, D, C, B, A, and N must be on the table.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an agent that can manipulate only vowel-labelled blocks (A, E, I). Describe your local operational model, constraints, and a concise local plan that lists what top vowel blocks you can currently move and where they can legally go. Provide the description in a structured and precise way so an orchestrator can integrate it into a global planning model.
pddl.prompt: Agent name: vowel_agent. Use the public information about the environment and your private information to list: 1) which stacks expose vowel blocks at the top, 2) the legal move types you can perform and their preconditions and effects in natural language, and 3) a short local plan fragment (sequence of allowed moves) for the vowel blocks you can manipulate given the initial state. Do not invent capabilities you do not have. Output should be precise and structured for integration.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an agent that can manipulate only consonant-labelled blocks. Describe your local operational model, constraints, and a concise local plan that lists what top consonant blocks you can currently move and where they can legally go. Provide the description in a structured and precise way so an orchestrator can integrate it into a global planning model.
pddl.prompt: Agent name: consonant_agent. Use the public information about the environment and your private information to list: 1) which stacks expose consonant blocks at the top, 2) the legal move types you can perform and their preconditions and effects in natural language, and 3) a short local plan fragment (sequence of allowed moves) for the consonant blocks you can manipulate given the initial state. Do not invent capabilities you do not have. Output should be precise and structured for integration.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert orchestrator that integrates partial local models from multiple agents into a single PDDL domain and problem compatible with the FastDownwards planner. Keep actions of different agents distinct by naming or typing them so the planner can assign them separately if needed. Use only FastDownwards-compatible features (STRIPS and commonly supported extensions) and avoid planner-specific proprietary constructs. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. The final PDDL must encode the initial stacks, the allowed moves (respecting top-only and vowel/consonant restrictions), and the global goal stack order.
pddl.prompt: You receive the local descriptions from two agents that are constrained to move only top blocks and one block at a time. Integrate their information, resolve naming or reference ambiguities, and produce a complete PDDL domain and PDDL problem targeting the FastDownwards solver that achieves the global goal. Keep the actions produced for the vowel agent distinct from those for the consonant agent (for example by prefixing action names). Make sure the domain includes predicates for on, ontable, clear, holding, and agent-specific move actions, and that the problem encodes the initial state and the goal stack N, M, L, K, J, I, H, G, F, E, D, C, B, A (N on table). Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
